nodes.body: Marked as awaiting review, but no way is this ready. I could use guidance on how to clean up the terrible duplication in the several symmetric arguments made here.
Thanks @grunweg and @brandon-sisler for your feedback. Working on a refactor now...

> Well, the problem is that when reviewing this PR it is not clear whether the changes are already taken care of in the other, so it is better to avoid duplicating the changes.

I'm now waiting on https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13515 to be merged into master. I'll then update this PR and hopefully this will then be ready to go as well.

@StevenClontz see what I did to the PR description. This is how you specify that this PR should wait until #13515 is finished (for which I just hit merge), and a GitHub bot will automatically post on this PR.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#13515~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
I think this is good to go if @grunweg or @faenuccio want to confirm.

### PR summary [5c46e91ec2](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13176/commits/5c46e91ec2a0f59c2458f201d9f7269d2e85e8a2)

#### Import changes

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Topology.Separation | 612 | 615 | +3 (+0.49%) |

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ HasSeparatingCover`
`+ IsClosed.HasSeparatingCover`
`+ IsLindelof.indexed_countable_subcover`
`+ closure_iUnion‚ÇÇ_le_nat`
`+ closure_iUnion‚ÇÇ_lt_nat`
`+ hasSeparatingCovers_iff_separatedNhds`
`+ instance (priority := 100) NormalSpace.of_regularSpace_lindelofSpace`
`+ interior_iInter‚ÇÇ_le_nat`
`+ interior_iInter‚ÇÇ_lt_nat`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>
Thanks! I think this is ready to go, I will let @j-loreaux or @urkud have a final look and merge.
Given the very thorough and instructive review by @PatrickMassot , I'll leave it to him to take further decisions on this PR.

I think the only remaining fix is the one you wanted: when arguments inside ‚ü® ‚ü© are on their own lines, they are aligned, as in the example I pointed in the style guide. After fixing that you can type 
bors merge 
in a GitHub comment and bors will do it because I am now telling it:
bors d+

:v: StevenClontz can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9530901445/job/26271282597)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9530901445/job/26271282423)
I left some style comments: I just saw these never got posted, oh no. Hopefully they're still useful.

Thanks! I made quite a few stylistic remarks since you are still a recent contributor. 

The main thing is really that you should learn to love the generalized projection notation (aka dot notation) because it really unclutters proof terms and almost always lead to a more natural reading order.

Asking since this is not obvious to me, within 30 seconds: do you have a particular reason for splitting out this file? (Or could this, for instance, move into `Compactness/Lindel√∂f`? I'm not saying that would be better, but I'd like to understand the *why* better.)

If splitthing this out is the better option, please add a module docstring to this file. Then, then linter will be happy - and later users looking at this file know what it's about. :-) If you're unsure what to put here, [this guide](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/doc.html) could help.

It's a naive attempt to fix a circular dependency caused by importing `Mathlib.Topology.Compactness.Lindelof` into `Mathlib.Topology.Separation` as-is. This change removes the dependency on `Mathlib.Topology.Metrizable.Basic` in `Mathlib.Topology.Compactness.Lindelof`. (Certainly there may be a slicker solution.)
:bulb: makes sense! (I didn't think hard whether there are better solutions: yours can certainly be a reasonable option.)
Here's a trick: `have` can take parameters, so could write this as `have hU (z) : U z ‚àà ùìù z := by` and remove the `intro z` line.
This file is a verbatim copy of what's already in mathlib, only factored out to a separate file for dependency reasons, so I'm inclined to leave it as-is for this PR.

I see. In principle, I very much agree to not delay every code motion by drive-by refactoring. In practice, Github's interface doesn't show code motion, so moved code often gets re-reviewed, for pre-existing issues :-(

How about this: would you like to make a PR to this code on `master`, with the changes I suggested? I can approve that one quickly, and then this PR can move the tweaked code. (I can also make that PR, but then I need to find another reviewer.)
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13515
Oh I just realized I did the move in that PR rather than just fixing the issues you pointed out; hopefully that's not a big deal.
Well, the problem is that when reviewing this PR it is not clear whether the changes are already taken care of in the other, so it is better to avoid duplicating the changes.

Since the `have` is so short and only used once, I would inline it (i.e., replace `this` by the proof directly).
Then, you can use dot notation: since `this` has type `IsOpen something` and the first hypothesis of `IsOpen.mem_nhds` is `IsOpen something`, you can equivalently write `this.mem_nhds` instead.
After these two steps, you end up at these two lines
```lean
    have hU (z) : U z ‚àà ùìù z := by
      refine (Metric.isOpen_ball).mem_nhds ?hx
```

Looking at the goal state here, it feels like there should be a lemma for this - and there is. Running `exact?` produces `exact Metric.mem_ball_self hpos`. Since that is also very short, I'd inline it into the `refine` - so you end up with a one-line proof. Finally, you can remove the `by refine`:
`have hU (z) : U z ‚àà ùìù z := (Metric.isOpen_ball).mem_nhds (Metric.mem_ball_self hpos)`

I think using `obtain` for this destructuring is more common style. Same below.
```suggestion
    obtain ‚ü®t, hct, huniv‚ü© := LindelofSpace.elim_nhds_subcover U hU

You could even inline the previous `have` into this obtain: I would do so, since `hU` is mathematically trivial. You end up at
```
obtain ‚ü®t, hct, huniv‚ü© := LindelofSpace.elim_nhds_subcover U
      (fun _ ‚Ü¶ (Metric.isOpen_ball).mem_nhds (Metric.mem_ball_self hpos))

Style comment: mathlib style is to have no spaces around the angular brackets. This also applies in a number of places below
```suggestion
  rcases h_cov with ‚ü®u, c, c_count, c_cov, u_props‚ü©

This is perfectly correct code - you can write it more compactly if you like.
- You can add the proof terms directly to the `IsOpen.sdiff` call, like `IsOpen.sdiff (u_props (f n)).1 isClosed_closure`.
- You can also move the `intro n` into a proof term, as `fun n ‚Ü¶ IsOpen.sdiff (u_props (f n)).1 isClosed_closure`. If you're not sure why, feel free to ask. I don't want to 'splain you.
- Inlining the proof term again, you obtain `exact isOpen_iUnion fun n ‚Ü¶ IsOpen.sdiff (u_props (f n)).1 isClosed_closure`.

The same trick works once more.
You can combine
exact isOpen_iUnion fun n ‚Ü¶ IsOpen.sdiff (u_props (f n)).1 isClosed_closure

Thanks! I didn't catch this before I synced up today with a former student who did a Lean summer camp last summer, and he gave similar advice. We now

```lean
  have open_lemma : ‚àÄ (u‚ÇÄ a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí Set X), (‚àÄ n, IsOpen (u‚ÇÄ n)) ‚Üí
    IsOpen (‚ãÉ n, u‚ÇÄ n \ closure (a n)) := fun _ _ u‚ÇÄi_open =>
    isOpen_iUnion (fun i => IsOpen.sdiff (u‚ÇÄi_open i) (isClosed_closure))
```
This is one more opportunity for dot notation: `apply kcl.compl_mem_nhds`

Another trick: for conjunctions with more than two clauses, `constructor` will only unpack them into two subgoals at the time. (I presume this is because ‚àßis a binary operation - so Lean "internally" parentheses this as "a ‚àß(b ‚àß(c ‚àßd) )".

`refine` allows you to unpack more goals at a time, as in `refine ‚ü®?_, ?_, ?_‚ü©`: each `?_` is a new sub-goal.
Of course, then you can inline easy proof-terms again, and could end up at e.g. this
```
refine ‚ü®interior n, isOpen_interior, ?_, fun _ ‚Ü¶ mem_interior_iff_mem_nhds.mpr nna‚ü©
```

In general, all this compressing code is a trade-off: my rule of thumb is that "mathematically trivial" steps can be condensed to maximum degree - but for non-trivial steps, readability counts more.
Also works once again below.
Oh cool - I knew the chained `constructor`s was smelly. Thanks for this tip.

```suggestion
    simp only [subset_eq_empty c_cov rfl, empty_subset, exists_const]
```
Do you know that if you like this suggestion you can click on "commit suggestion" that would automatically modify the file and commit the result to the PR?
Yep, but I want to try it out myself first.
Sure, even better! I just wanted to make sure that you knew how to proceed. Apologies for the triviality ;-)

You can also write
```lean
obtain ‚ü®c, ‚ü®c_count, c_cov‚ü©‚ü© := IsLindelof.elim_countable_subcover hs U hUo hsU
```
There is no clear preference, but the `obtain` keyword makes it clear that you are constructing something. At any rate, obtain is an `rcases` after all, so it's up to you.
Yes - @grunweg pointed this tactic out where `have` was used similarly in some code I (didn't write and) moved around above. I much prefer the word `obtain` for making things clear here. Thanks!
Again, could use `obtain`.

```suggestion
  rcases (Set.countable_iff_exists_surjective c_nonempty).mp c_count with ‚ü®f, f_surj‚ü©
  refine ‚ü®Subtype.val ‚àò f, Subset.trans c_cov ?_‚ü©
  simp only [Function.comp_apply, iUnion_subset_iff]
  intro x hx
  obtain ‚ü®n, hn‚ü© := f_surj ‚ü®x, hx‚ü©
  exact subset_iUnion_of_subset n <| subset_of_eq (by rw [hn])
```

```suggestion
# Second-countability of pseudometrizable Lindel√∂f spaces
```
Can you add in the doc some references to Lindel√∂f spaces and to the way some separation axioms are deduced through the theory of Lindel√∂f spaces?

```suggestion
/-- Lemma used to prove that a regular topological space with Lindel√∂f topology is a normal space,
```
Can you also add this todo to the beginning of the file, where it will be easier to spot?
What I meant by "references" was to add external references, like a wikipedia entry or (better) a book/chapter of a book.

Well, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_axiom is already referenced. I'll add https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal_space since it asserts the specific result. I could add a book, but this is pretty standard stuff so honestly any graduate-level topology textbook (Engelking, Munkres, Willard, etc) would have this result.

I have Engelking handy and this is a consequence of the first few results in 5.1 Paracompact spaces (but that's not a great reference as Engelking loves to overload separation axioms into his definitions for covering properties, hiding the regularity requirement).

My only point is that I find it nice that for "classical" results we indicate that what is being formalized can be also read on paper, to make a nice connection with the "real world". This should really not be a pain for you, I was just suggesting this as you are clearly much more knowledgeable on the existing grad/undergrad literature.

This does reveal that eventually this should be improved to show that every regular Lindelof space is fully normal (equivalently in this context, paracompact). But TBH this was a specific TODO that I was trying to address at https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/04c29e2530bb437a841451567fa770f65183f6b5/Mathlib/Topology/Separation.lean#L2291 so I didn't want to go overboard.
I'll head to the office tomorrow and see if there's a clean reference that uses modern definitions of separation axioms and covering properties. (I think Willard does this carefully.)
addressed in 53b8f7b

It is somewhat strange to have this two long assumptions `h_cov` and `k_cov` at the beginning: is it something that you would expect to use in other occasions or are there just extremely localised properties of a pair of covers? Because in the first case I would suggest that you create a `definition` or a `structure` to contain these properties, in the same spirit as `SperatedNhds`

Hmm, this occurred to me at the time. I actually think `h_cov /\ k_cov <-> SeparatedNhds h k`, (oh of course, for the other direction, u is the constant function yielding the appropriate separating nhd). I'll play around with this, thanks.
Introduced as `SeparatingCover` in [9daaadf](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13176/commits/9daaadff9c8cd293824a72bb2cef14ad5459780f)

```suggestion
  rcases h_cov, k_cov with ‚ü®‚ü®u, u_cov, u_props‚ü©, ‚ü®v, v_cov, v_props‚ü©‚ü©
```

```suggestion
  use ‚ãÉ n : ‚Ñï, u n \ (closure (‚ãÉ m ‚àà {m | m ‚â§ n}, v m)), 
    ‚ãÉ n : ‚Ñï, v n \ (closure (‚ãÉ m ‚àà {m | m ‚â§ n}, u m))
```

Don't these two open/cover lemma really deserve any independent status that would make it worth to single them out of the proof? In other words, would you expect them to be potentielly useful in other proofs?

For `open_lemma`, that seems possible. I'd thought about it but wasn't sure where the threshold was.

Maybe `cover_lemma` too. I'll stew on it.
I think the necessity of this will be clear as I work on #13517, and I think it's best to defer this to that PR.

```suggestion
    refine ‚ü®n, xinun, ?_‚ü©
```

```suggestion
    rw [Set.Finite.closure_biUnion (finite_le_nat n)]
    simp_all only [disjoint_right, mem_setOf_eq, mem_iUnion, exists_false, exists_const,
      not_false_eq_true]
```

```suggestion
    ¬∑ exact ‚ü®u ‚àò f, ‚ü®f_cov, fun n ‚Ü¶ ‚ü®u_open (f n), u_dis (f n)‚ü©‚ü©‚ü©
    ¬∑ exact ‚ü®v ‚àò g, ‚ü®g_cov, fun n ‚Ü¶ ‚ü®v_open (g n), v_dis (g n)‚ü©‚ü©‚ü©
```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion use ‚ãÉ n : ‚Ñï, u n \ (closure (‚ãÉ m ‚àà {m | m ‚â§ n}, v m)), ```

Thanks, can you please follow the instructions here
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/doc.html#citing-other-works
for these references (both the wikipedia and the Willard one)?

I don't see any information on wikipedia links in that document, or any wikipedia sources listed in docs/references.bib

I'll add the Willard text there.

```suggestion
def SeparatingCover : Set X ‚Üí Set X ‚Üí Prop := fun s t ‚Ü¶
```

```suggestion
      rcases h‚ÇÄ_cov xinh with ‚ü®un , ‚ü®n, rfl‚ü© , xinun‚ü©
```

```suggestion
    rintro x ‚ü®un, ‚ü®n, rfl‚ü©, xinun‚ü©
```
Once you will have added the reference to the main bib file this citation style can be made uniform. The reason for this is the smooth interaction with the doc website.
Given that the proof is somewhat long, would it be possible to add some comments along it explaining the main lines?
Done in 66db844
I am still thinking about a way to avoid some code duplication here.
I think 7286de7 is what we want.

```suggestion
* <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_axiom>
* <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal_space>
```
This makes the link clickable when the website is built.
Please use dot notation here, and remove useless parentheses around a single word.
This name does not suggest a Prop to me. I would have guessed that `SeparatingCover s t` would be the property satisfied by `u` here. What do you think about renaming this to `HasSeparatingCover`?
I like it. 5b96863
The idiomatic way of doing this is `rcases c.eq_empty_or_nonempty with rfl | c_nonempty` which will save you the trouble of using `not_nonempty_iff_eq_empty`.
Nice: 80b6506

```suggestion
  refine ‚ü®Subtype.val ‚àò f, c_cov.trans  ?_‚ü©
```

Or you could even go all the way to 
`refine ‚ü®fun x ‚Ü¶ f x, c_cov.trans  <| iUnion‚ÇÇ_subset_iff.mpr (?_ : ‚àÄ i ‚àà c, U i ‚äÜ ‚ãÉ n, U (f n))‚ü©`
if you want to already clean up the next goal.
Thanks: 80b6506
This is really not a nice looking spelling. If we are missing lemmas to write `‚ãÉ m ‚â§ n, v‚ÇÄ m` then we should add them instead of using the ugly spelling.
Indeed I tried `‚ãÉ m ‚â§ n, v‚ÇÄ m` but struggled. Will take another stab at this (and add a lemma if needed).

Accomplished with https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/compare/0f84d6b0c33c428f4a59d90497e3a430ff69acdf..da47eb219d095e1e73c5d666de249def9c28748d - I suspect there's a better name than `closure_iUnion‚ÇÇ_of_finite`. ~~And the CI failed so I'm addressing that now.~~ (fixed)
Why is this line unindented?
The indentation of this block is pretty confusing. Also please use dot notation.
Thoughts on 3419b6b ?
Please use dot notation: `h_sub_U.trans (iUnion_const U).symm.subset` should work here.
Same remark as above.

Note you can be nicer to readers by saying what you will reduce to. Say the goal after this `simp only` is `foo`. Then you can replace this line with `suffices foo by simpa` (this is assuming all lemmas in your `simp` are already `simp` lemmas, otherwise you need to give them to `simpa`).
[`fafa4ae`](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13176/commits/fafa4ae78bddf1764eef0a4487e1b8b7a801c93a)

This a really weird move that is bound to lead to a confusing tactic state since Lean has no way to guess what would be the right hand-side. Can‚Äôt you simply stick a `|>.1` at the end of the next line? Of course using parentheses is also fine.

```suggestion
  obtain ‚ü®f, f_cov‚ü© := s_cl.isLindelof.indexed_countable_subcover
```
dot notation‚Ä¶
This name is the wrong way around, it should be `IsClosed.SeparatingCover` or, better, `IsClosed.HasSeparatingCover` so that you can use it with dot notation.
This is not a good name, it is not specific enough. Maybe `closure_iUnion‚ÇÇ_le_nat`?
I‚Äôm pretty sure this is `rfl`
Please use dot notation.
Again this should be true by definition. If this is true then the whole proof should be `:= (finite_le_nat n).closure_biUnion f`, without entering tactic mode.
Please use dot notation.

`has_separating_covers_iff_separated_nhds` is not following the name convention. It should be `hasSeparatingCovers_iff_separated_nhds`. The point is that underscores separate the different Lean declarations that are involved. This makes it much easier to see that this lemma is about `HasSeparatingCovers`.
bc8a5bf
See above remark about this name.
bc8a5bf

This is still not following https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html. The opening ‚ü® should not be orphaned. Please see the last paragraph before https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html#instances

I think I've corrected this to follow the style guide. (Aside, it's unforunate that this style causes the first argument to be offset horizontally from its sibling arguments.)

3a2386b
No it doesn‚Äôt offset. Did you look precisely where I said?

I believe so? 

![Screenshot_20240615-160724](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/assets/1559632/e926434d-ba6c-47c0-917c-feca3cc6528a)

This might make my concern clearer.

![Screenshot_20240615-161058](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/assets/1559632/320554a6-18b2-4c75-a76f-03099afeaa78)

On mobile but I think I realized what's happening: my editor and the docs webpage (on both my laptop and phone browser) are probably rendering that angle bracket as half-width. I can make it align, pretending it was rendered full width.
Same here.
Same here.
The second level of ‚ü®‚ü© nesting should not be necessary.
Orphaned ‚ü®

The main thing is really that you should learn to love the generalized projection notation (aka dot notation) because it really unclutters proof terms and almost always lead to a more natural reading order.

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore: implement final style feedback from #13176
